Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: I stared at the clock on my computer screen, watching the seconds tick closer to the start of Sunday worship. My headset itched against my ear as I listened to the monotone ring of another unanswered call. As a telemarketer, I was expected to stick to my schedule, take breaks only when allowed, and never let the automated compliance system catch me away from my desk. Even a minute of unscheduled downtime could mean a warning or worse. But as a Christian, Sunday worship was more than a routine—it was a time to reconnect with my faith and my community, to sing, pray, and feel a sense of belonging. I could almost hear the hymns starting, the gentle murmur of prayers, and I longed to be there. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the strict rules. My pastor’s words, too, about the importance of gathering together. My heart pounded as I hovered over the “log out” button, torn between the demands of my job and the pull of my faith, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
